name: Polymorphic Open/Closed Principle
description: A principle that states software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification, promoting the use of abstract base classes and interfaces.

description: A principle that ensures objects of a superclass shall be replaceable with objects of a subclass without affecting the correctness of the program.

name: Singleton

name: Factory

name: Open/Closed Principle (OCP)
description: A design principle that states software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.;A design principle that states software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification, promoting a hierarchy of components.

name: FinancialDataGateway

name: FinancialReportRequester

name: Interface Segregation Principle

name: Component Hierarchy

name: Dependency Inversion

name: Polymorphism

name: High-Level Module (HL1)

description: A principle that states a class should have only one reason to change, promoting separation of concerns.

name: Open-Closed Principle
description: A principle that suggests software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.

name: Liskov Substitution Principle
description: A principle that states objects of a superclass should be replaceable with objects of a subclass without affecting the correctness of the program.

name: Interface Segregation Principle
description: A principle that advocates for many client-specific interfaces rather than one general-purpose interface.

name: Dependency Inversion Principle
description: A principle that suggests high-level modules should not depend on low-level modules but both should depend on abstractions.

name: Clean Architecture

name: Facade
description: A design pattern that provides a simplified interface to a complex subsystem.

name: Component
description: A modular part of a system that encapsulates a set of related functions and data.

description: An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of loosely coupled services.

name: Component

description: A principle that suggests components should be grouped together based on their closure to changes, promoting stability.

name: Component
description: A modular unit of software that encapsulates a specific functionality and can be independently developed and maintained.

name: Dependency Inversion Principle

description: A structure that prevents cycles in component dependencies, promoting stability in development environments.

name: Dependency Inversion Principle
description: A principle that suggests high-level modules should not depend on low-level modules, but both should depend on abstractions.

description: A principle that states a class should have only one reason to change, focusing on a single responsibility.;A principle that states that a class should have only one reason to change, promoting separation of concerns.

name: Component Structure
description: The organization of components within a system, which can evolve as the system grows.;The organization of components within a system, which can evolve as the application grows and changes.

name: Layers Pattern
description: An architectural pattern that organizes the system into layers, each with distinct responsibilities.

name: Pipe-and-Filter Pattern
description: An architectural pattern that breaks down a process into a series of discrete components (filters) connected by data streams (pipes).

name: Publish-Subscribe Pattern
description: An architectural pattern that allows components to communicate with each other without being tightly coupled, using a message broker.

name: Service-Oriented Pattern
description: An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of loosely coupled services.

name: Quality Attributes
description: Characteristics that affect the performance, maintainability, scalability, security, and reliability of a software system.

description: Documentation that captures important decisions made during the architecture design process.

name: Performance

name: Module

name: Cohesion
description: A quality attribute that measures how closely related and focused the responsibilities of a single module are.

name: Coupling
description: A quality attribute that measures the degree of interdependence between software modules, with low coupling being desirable.

name: Layered Architecture
description: An architectural pattern that organizes software into layers, each with specific responsibilities, facilitating separation of concerns.

name: Low Coupling
description: A design principle that advocates for minimal dependencies between components to enhance maintainability and flexibility.

name: High Cohesion
description: A design principle that promotes grouping related functionalities within a component to improve understandability and reusability.

name: Reactor
description: A design pattern that handles service requests delivered concurrently to a service handler by one or more inputs.

name: Concurrency Strategy
description: A code structure that defines how concurrent operations are managed within the web server framework.

description: A code structure that allows for the configuration and management of components within the web server framework.

description: Architectural design considerations specific to web server implementations, including concurrency and protocol handling.

name: Performance
description: The efficiency of a system in terms of response time and resource usage.

name: Security
description: The protection of the system against unauthorized access and data breaches.

name: Reliability
description: The ability of a system to consistently perform its intended functions.

name: Keep It Simple
description: A design principle that emphasizes simplicity in design to reduce complexity and potential bugs.

description: A principle that encourages designs to be open-ended and easily extendable to accommodate future requirements.

description: An iterative software development process that emphasizes risk assessment and iterative refinement.

description: A software development methodology that promotes iterative development and customer collaboration.

description: A software development methodology that emphasizes customer satisfaction and rapid iterations.

name: User Story
description: A tool used in Agile methodologies to capture system requirements from the user's perspective.

description: A design principle that involves creating a high-level prototype to validate design concepts before full implementation.

description: A form of inheritance that allows an object to be used in place of another based on its interface rather than its implementation.

name: Design Patterns
description: A collection of best practices for software design that provide solutions to common problems.

description: A creational design pattern that restricts the instantiation of a class to one single instance.

name: Factory
description: A creational design pattern that provides an interface for creating objects in a superclass but allows subclasses to alter the type of created objects.

name: Maintainability
description: A software quality attribute that measures how easily a software system can be modified.

name: Scalability
description: The capability of a system to handle a growing amount of work or its potential to accommodate growth.

description: A quality attribute that refers to the responsiveness of a system and its ability to process requests in a timely manner.

description: Ensures a class has only one instance and provides a global point of access to it.

description: Encapsulates a request as an object, allowing parameterization of clients with different requests and supporting undoable operations.

name: Adapter Pattern

description: The entity that maintains a list of observers and notifies them of state changes.

description: A design principle stating that software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.

name: Liskov Substitution Principle (LSP)
description: A principle that states subclasses should be substitutable for their base classes without altering the correctness of the program.

description: An example illustrating the violation of the Liskov Substitution Principle.

name: Open Closed Principle
description: A principle that states software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.

name: Liskov Substitution Principle
description: A principle that states objects of a superclass should be replaceable with objects of a subclass without affecting the correctness of the program.

name: Stability

name: Instability

name: value object

name: Cold Spare
description: A redundancy approach where backup components are inactive until needed, resulting in longer recovery times.

name: Rollback Technique

name: External Coupling
description: Refers to the dependency of multiple modules on the same external environment, emphasizing the need to limit such dependencies to enhance maintainability.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Control Coupling
description: A moderate type of coupling where one module controls the internal logic of another by passing information, which can affect maintainability and testability.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Stamp Coupling
description: A low type of coupling that occurs when modules share a composite data structure, which may lead to unnecessary dependencies and reduced maintainability.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Data Coupling
description: Occurs when two modules share primitive data values, representing a common and acceptable interaction method that supports maintainability.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Message Coupling
description: The lowest type of coupling where one module calls a method on another without sending parameters, promoting high modularity and low dependency.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: No Coupling
description: An ideal state where two modules have no direct communication, enhancing modularity and maintainability.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Module Cohesion
description: Refers to the degree to which elements within a module belong together, impacting maintainability and reusability.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Logical Cohesion
description: A type of cohesion where elements are grouped logically, but may not be highly cohesive, affecting maintainability.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Temporal Cohesion
description: A type of cohesion where elements are grouped based on timing of execution, leading to low maintainability.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Procedural Cohesion
description: A type of cohesion where elements are grouped by the sequence of execution, which can be moderate in maintainability.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

name: Communicational Cohesion
description: A type of cohesion where elements are grouped because they share the same inputs and outputs, affecting module clarity.
source: Joseph Ingeno - Software Architects Handbook_ Become a successful software architect by implementing effective architecture concepts-Packt Publishing (2018).pdf

description: An architectural pattern that separates application logic into multiple tiers, commonly including presentation, business, and data layers.

name: Extract Function

name: Push Down Field

description: Refactoring technique used to move methods from one class to another, enhancing code organization.

name: Replace Subclass with Delegate
description: A design pattern that suggests using delegation instead of inheritance to reduce coupling and improve flexibility.

name: State Pattern

name: Strategy Pattern
description: A behavioral design pattern that enables selecting an algorithm's behavior at runtime.

name: Factory Function
description: A creational design pattern that provides a way to create objects without specifying the exact class of the object that will be created.

name: Module
description: A self-contained unit of code that encapsulates related functions and data, promoting code organization and reuse.

name: Superclass
description: A class that is inherited from by one or more subclasses, providing a base for shared functionality.

name: Delegate Class

name: Factory Function
description: A design pattern that provides a way to create objects without specifying the exact class of the object that will be created.

name: Person
description: An entity representing a person, which can be extended by subclasses like Male and Female.

description: A subclass of Person representing male individuals, demonstrating inheritance.

name: Replace Constructor with Factory Function
description: A refactoring pattern that replaces direct constructor calls with a factory function to encapsulate object creation.

name: Extract Function
description: A refactoring technique that creates a new function from a portion of existing code to improve readability and reusability.

name: Inline Variable
description: A refactoring technique that removes a variable and replaces its occurrences with the expression it holds, simplifying the code.

name: Push Down Method
description: Refactoring technique to move methods down the class hierarchy to reduce unused code in superclasses.

name: Push Down Field
description: Refactoring technique to move fields down the class hierarchy to ensure superclasses only hold common data.

name: Replace Subclass with Delegate
description: Refactoring technique that replaces subclassing with delegation to avoid issues with superclass interfaces.

name: Replace Superclass with Delegate
description: Refactoring technique that replaces a superclass with a delegate to simplify class hierarchies.

name: Extract Function
description: Refactoring technique that creates a new function from a block of code to improve readability and reduce complexity.

name: Change Function Declaration
description: Refactoring technique that renames a function to better reflect its purpose, enhancing code clarity.

name: Introduce Assertion
description: Refactoring technique that adds assertions to enforce rules about the state of the system.

name: SOLID Principles
description: A set of five principles that guide software design to create more understandable, flexible, and maintainable code.

name: DRY Principle
description: The 'Don't Repeat Yourself' principle aims to reduce the repetition of code patterns, promoting reusability.

name: KISS Principle
description: The 'Keep It Simple, Stupid' principle emphasizes simplicity in design to avoid unnecessary complexity.

name: YAGNI Principle
description: The 'You Aren't Gonna Need It' principle advises against adding functionality until it is necessary.

name: Encapsulate Record
description: A design pattern that groups related data into a single record structure to improve code organization and encapsulation.

name: Introduce Parameter Object
description: A design pattern that creates a new object to group parameters together, simplifying method signatures and enhancing readability.

name: Move Function
description: A design pattern that involves relocating a function to a more appropriate class or module to improve cohesion.

name: Extract Function
description: A design pattern that refactors code by extracting a portion of logic into a separate function to enhance clarity and reusability.

name: Encapsulate Collection
description: A design pattern that hides the details of a collection's implementation, providing a cleaner interface for interaction.

name: Replace Primitive with Object
description: A design pattern that replaces primitive data types with objects to enhance flexibility and encapsulation.

name: Replace Temp with Query
description: A design pattern that replaces temporary variables with queries to improve code clarity and reduce dependencies.

name: Module
description: A code organization structure that encapsulates related functions and data, promoting separation of concerns.

name: Class
description: A fundamental code structure in object-oriented programming that encapsulates data and behavior.

name: Module
description: A code structure that encapsulates a set of related functions or classes, promoting organization and reusability.

name: Is-Composed-Of Relation
description: A design pattern that describes how components are organized within a system, indicating a hierarchical structure.

name: Is-A Relationship
description: A relationship in object-oriented design indicating inheritance, where one class is a specialized version of another.

name: Has-A Relationship
description: A relationship in object-oriented design indicating composition, where one class contains instances of another class.

name: Separation of Policy and Mechanism
description: A design principle that advocates for separating the policy (what to do) from the mechanism (how to do it) to enhance flexibility.

name: Program Families
description: A collection of related modules or subsystems that form a framework, facilitating the organization of related functionalities.

name: Framework
description: A set of abstract and concrete classes that provide a reusable design structure for software development.

name: Modularity
description: A system structure composed of independent modules that encapsulate abstractions.

name: High Cohesion
description: A principle that suggests modules should focus on a single task or responsibility.

name: Low Coupling
description: A principle that emphasizes minimizing dependencies between modules.

name: Separation of Concerns
description: A design principle for separating a computer program into distinct sections.

name: Extensibility
description: The ability of a system to accommodate growth and new features.

name: Reusability
description: The capability of a module to be used in different contexts without modification.

name: Compatibility
description: The ability of a system to work with other systems or modules.

name: Portability
description: The ease with which software can be transferred from one environment to another.

name: Module Interface
description: Defines the services requested and provided by a module, including access control.

name: Information Hiding
description: A principle that restricts access to certain details of a module to reduce complexity.

name: Dependency Inversion Principle
description: A principle stating that high-level modules should not depend on low-level modules, but both should depend on abstractions.

name: Open/Closed Principle
description: Software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification, promoting maintainability.

name: Liskov Substitution Principle
description: Derived classes must be substitutable for their base classes without altering the correctness of the program.

name: High-Level Prototyping
description: A design approach that involves creating a prototype to validate design criteria before full implementation.

name: Abstract Classes
description: Classes that cannot be instantiated and are meant to be subclassed, promoting a stable architecture.

name: Component Dependency Structure
description: A structure where dependencies between released components must form a Directed Acyclic Graph (DAG).

name: Interface Layer
description: A layer that separates different paradigms to prevent pollution of one side with the other.

name: Consistency Between Representations
description: Ensuring that the final implementation is consistent with the high-level design.

name: Functional Fixedness
description: A cognitive bias that limits a person's ability to use an object only in the way it is traditionally used, impacting problem-solving in design.

name: Convergent Thinking
description: A thought process that narrows down multiple ideas into a single solution, important for finalizing design decisions.

name: Adapter
description: A structural design pattern that allows incompatible interfaces to work together.

name: Composite
description: A structural design pattern that allows you to compose objects into tree structures to represent part-whole hierarchies.

name: Facade
description: A structural design pattern that provides a simplified interface to a complex subsystem.

name: Iterator
description: A behavioral design pattern that provides a way to access the elements of an aggregate object sequentially without exposing its underlying representation.

name: Observer
description: A behavioral design pattern that defines a one-to-many dependency between objects so that when one object changes state, all its dependents are notified and updated automatically.

name: Principles of Software Architecture
description: Fundamental guidelines that inform the design and structure of software architecture.

name: Singleton
description: A creational design pattern that restricts the instantiation of a class to one single instance.

description: A type of cohesion where tasks are grouped together because they are executed at the same time.

description: An object that is defined by its identity, rather than its attributes.

name: SOAP (Simple Object Access Protocol)

name: Service Integration Layer
description: A layer that facilitates the integration of various services, allowing for dynamic service selection and composition.

name: Demand-led Service Model
description: An architectural model where services are dynamically selected based on user demand, allowing for greater flexibility.

name: Supply-led Service Model
description: An architectural model where a predetermined set of services is provided by a supplier, limiting flexibility.

name: Top-down decomposition
description: An architectural style that breaks down a system into smaller, manageable components, facilitating easier understanding and modification.
source: Software Design  Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Modularity
description: A design principle that emphasizes dividing a program into distinct modules that can be developed, tested, and maintained independently.

name: Stepwise refinement
description: A design approach that involves breaking down a complex problem into simpler sub-problems, allowing for incremental development and refinement.
source: Software Design  Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Information hiding
description: A principle that suggests that modules should hide their internal workings and expose only what is necessary, promoting encapsulation and reducing dependencies.
source: Software Design  Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Maintainability
description: A software quality attribute that refers to the ease with which a software system can be modified to correct faults, improve performance, or adapt to a changed environment.
source: Software Design  Creating Solutions for Ill-Structured Problems.pdf

name: Design Strategies

description: The ease with which software can be modified to correct faults, improve performance, or adapt to a changed environment.

name: Observer
description: A behavioral design pattern that defines a one-to-many dependency between objects, allowing one object to notify others about changes in its state.

description: An interface that defines the methods for registering, removing, and notifying observers in the Observer pattern.

description: Adaptation Adjustment Multiplier that reflects the additional effort required to reuse components.

name: AA
description: Assessment factor representing the effort involved in deciding whether or not to reuse components.

name: SU
description: Understanding component representing the costs of understanding the code to be reused.

name: AAF
description: Adaptation component representing the costs of making changes to the reused code.

description: A model used for estimating the effort required for software development, particularly in the context of reuse.

name: Bounded Context
description: A design boundary within which a particular model is defined and applicable, crucial for Domain-Driven Design.

name: Aggregate
description: A cluster of domain objects that can be treated as a single unit, important for maintaining consistency in Domain-Driven Design.

name: Entity
description: An object that is defined by its identity rather than its attributes, fundamental in Domain-Driven Design.

name: Value Object
description: An object that describes some characteristics or attributes but has no conceptual identity, used in Domain-Driven Design.

name: Ubiquitous Language
description: A common language used by both developers and non-developers to describe the domain, enhancing communication in Domain-Driven Design.

name: Codeline
description: A sequence of versions of source code, with later versions derived from earlier versions, typically applied to components of systems.

name: Baseline

name: Version Control System
description: Systems that identify, store, and control access to different versions of software components.

name: Centralized Version Control System
description: A version control system where a single master repository maintains all versions of the software components.

name: Distributed Version Control System
description: A version control system where multiple versions of the component repository exist simultaneously.

name: Component
description: A modular part of a system that can be versioned and referenced in baselines.

name: Version Control System
description: A system that manages changes to source code over time, allowing multiple developers to work on the same codebase without conflicts.

name: Component
description: A modular part of a system that encapsulates a set of related functions and data, facilitating code organization and reuse.

name: Workspace
description: A developer's local environment where they can work on code independently before integrating changes back to the main repository.

name: Clone
description: A copy of the repository that allows developers to work on their own version of the codebase without affecting the original.

name: Check-in
description: The process of submitting changes made in a workspace back to the repository, creating a new version of the component.

name: Check-out
description: The action of retrieving a component from the repository to work on it in a private workspace.

name: component-based software engineering (CBSE)
description: The development of software by composing independent, deployable software components.

name: dependability
description: An aggregate property reflecting safety, reliability, availability, security, and resilience of a system.

name: design pattern
description: A well-tried solution to a common problem that captures experience and good practice.

name: domain model
description: A definition of the domain that describes the problem space and its entities.

name: Checksum Management
description: A method for uniquely identifying source code files and their corresponding object code files using checksums, allowing for parallel compilation and version management.

name: Source Code File
description: The original code written by developers, which is compiled into object code.

name: Object Code File
description: The compiled version of the source code file, generated by the compiler.

name: Change Management Process
description: A structured approach to managing changes in software systems, ensuring that changes are controlled and prioritized effectively.

name: Version Control System

name: Branching
description: A design pattern used in version control to create independent lines of development.

name: Merging
description: A design pattern in version control that combines changes from different branches into a single version.

name: Delta Storage
description: A method of storing only the differences between versions to minimize disk space usage.

description: A modular part of a system that encapsulates functionality and can be developed independently.

name: Resilience

name: Content Coupling

name: Behavioral Diagrams
description: Diagrams that capture and specify the dynamic behavior and complexities of software systems.

name: Class Diagram

name: Object Diagram
description: A UML diagram that represents instances of classes and their relationships at a particular moment.

name: Sequence Diagram
description: A UML diagram that models the time-ordered sequence of operations among components in a system.

name: Deployment Diagram
description: A UML diagram that models the physical deployment of artifacts on nodes in a distributed system.

name: SensorManager

name: Object Composition

name: Generalization

name: Abstraction

name: Scalability

name: Maintainability
description: The ease with which a software system can be modified to correct faults, improve performance, or adapt to a changed environment.

name: Scalability
description: The capability of a system to handle a growing amount of work or its potential to accommodate growth.

description: A design principle that promotes the organization of code into separate modules to enhance maintainability and reusability.

name: Performance
description: A software quality attribute that measures the responsiveness and efficiency of a system, often influenced by concurrency.

name: Component
description: Represents a modular and replaceable part of the system, modeled using a box with the keyword <<component>>.

description: The principle that facilitates the analysis of architecture design, including performance and behavior considerations.

name: Module
description: A module is a self-contained unit of software that encapsulates a set of related functions and data.

name: Subsystem
description: A subsystem is a secondary system that is part of a larger system, often responsible for a specific functionality.

name: Component
description: A component is a modular part of a system that encapsulates a set of related functions and can be independently deployed.

name: Functional Requirement
description: Specifies the functionality that the software system must provide.

name: Nonfunctional Requirement
description: Specifies the quality attributes, constraints, and behaviors of the software system.

name: Box-and-Line Diagram
description: A conceptual model used to represent the architecture of a system, illustrating elements and their relationships.

name: Unified Modeling Language (UML)
description: A standardized modeling language used to specify, visualize, and document software system designs.

name: Data Flow Diagram (DFD)
description: A graphical representation of the flow of data within a system, used for analysis and design.

name: State Transition Diagram (STD)
description: A diagram that represents the states of a system and the transitions between those states.

name: Software Requirement Specification (SRS)
description: A document that describes the intended purpose and environment for software under development.

name: Controller Class
description: A class that manages the flow of the application and coordinates activities among other classes, typically associated with specific use cases.

name: Entity Class
description: Represents the information stored and exchanged among elements of the system, encapsulating the domain data.

name: Boundary Class
description: Acts as an interface between the system and the outside world, often represented by UI components.

name: Analysis Class Diagram
description: A diagram that describes key classes and their interrelationships in a system, focusing on abstractions and functionalities.

name: AmericanTaxPayer
description: An interface defining the operation ReportTax() that must be implemented by classes like AmericanLawyer and AmericanProfessor.

name: AmericanCitizenTaxHandler
description: A class responsible for processing the ReportTax() operation, providing a centralized implementation for tax reporting.

name: AmericanLawyer
description: A class representing a specific type of taxpayer that implements the AmericanTaxPayer interface.

name: AmericanProfessor
description: A class representing another type of taxpayer that implements the AmericanTaxPayer interface.

name: Order Processing System (OPS)
description: A system designed for managing online orders, requiring OO analysis and design.

name: Maintainability
description: A software quality attribute that ensures the system can be easily modified and updated.

name: Scalability
description: A quality attribute that allows the system to handle increased load without performance degradation.

name: OO Analysis
description: The initial stage of object-oriented development focused on understanding domain requirements.

name: OO Design
description: The stage where responsibilities and attributes of classes are defined based on the analysis.

name: Public Interface
description: Defines the operations and attributes that a class exposes to the outside world, ensuring stability and completeness.

name: Constructor Operation
description: A method used to initialize an object's data members upon creation, often part of the Factory pattern.

name: Destructor Operation
description: A method that cleans up resources when an object is no longer in use, important for resource management.

name: Accessor Operation
description: A method that retrieves information from an object without modifying its state, promoting encapsulation.

name: Mutator Operation
description: A method that modifies the state of an object, often leading to state transitions.

name: State Machine Diagram
description: A visual representation of the states and transitions of an object, aiding in understanding class behavior.

name: CRC Cards
description: A technique for identifying classes and their responsibilities, enhancing class design and collaboration.

name: Professor Class
description: A class that initially handles multiple responsibilities, leading to a lack of cohesion.

name: Advisor Class
description: A subclass of Professor that handles responsibilities related to advising students.

name: Instructor Class
description: A subclass of Professor that handles responsibilities related to course instruction.

name: Advisor Interface
description: An interface that declares operations for the Advisor class.

name: Instructor Interface
description: An interface that declares operations for the Instructor class.

name: Open-Closed Principle
description: A principle that states software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.

name: Abstraction via Inheritance and Polymorphism
description: A design approach that allows for extending functionality without modifying existing code.

name: Data Flow Architecture
description: An architectural style that views the software system as a series of transformations on data, emphasizing the independence of data and operations.

name: Batch Sequential Architecture
description: A data flow architecture where each module processes data in a sequence, waiting for the previous module to complete before starting.

name: Modifiability
description: A software quality attribute that emphasizes the ease with which a system can be modified.

name: Reusability
description: A quality attribute that allows components or subsystems to be reused in different contexts without modification.

name: Data Processing Element
description: A component in data flow architecture that transforms input data into output data.

name: Batch Sequential Architecture
description: A software architecture pattern where data is processed in batches sequentially, with each subsystem functioning independently.

name: Pipe and Filter Architecture
description: An architectural pattern that decomposes a system into components that process data streams, allowing for concurrent execution.

name: Static Methods
description: Methods that belong to a class rather than an instance, used in the batch sequential architecture example.

name: Data Stream
description: A mechanism for transmitting data between components in the Pipe and Filter architecture, functioning as a first-in/first-out buffer.

name: Active Filter
description: A filter in the Pipe and Filter architecture that pulls data from an upstream source and pushes transformed data downstream.

name: MVC Controller
description: Manages application flow by handling events and coordinating between views and models.

name: RegistrationController
description: A specific controller class responsible for handling registration-related web page events.

name: SessionController
description: A controller class that manages user sessions and interacts with customer information.

name: CustomerInformation
description: A class that holds customer data and is used by controllers for processing.

name: CustomerInfoDB
description: Database interface class that provides operations for accessing customer information.

name: Class-Responsibility-Collaborator (CRC) Card
description: A technique used to identify classes and their responsibilities in object-oriented design.

name: Sequence Diagram
description: A diagram that models the flow of events for use cases, showing interactions between objects.

name: High-Level Design
description: The stage of design where classes are identified and their responsibilities are assigned.

name: Low-Level Design
description: The stage of design where attributes and operations are assigned to classes based on interaction diagrams.

name: Use Case Diagram
description: A diagram that captures the functional requirements of a system and the interactions with users.

name: Cohesion
description: A measure of how closely related and focused the responsibilities of a single module are.

name: Coupling
description: A measure of how closely connected two modules are, with lower coupling generally being preferred.

name: Inheritance
description: A mechanism in object-oriented programming where a new class can inherit properties and behavior from an existing class.

name: Aggregation
description: A relationship where one class is a collection or container of other classes, but the contained classes can exist independently.

name: Composition
description: A strong relationship where one class is made up of one or more classes, and the contained classes cannot exist independently.

name: Open-Closed Principle
description: A principle stating that software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.

name: CRC Card Method
description: A collaborative design technique used to identify the responsibilities and collaborators of classes.

name: Sequence Diagram
description: A type of interaction diagram that shows how processes operate with one another and in what order.

name: State Machine Diagram
description: A diagram that represents the states of an object and transitions between those states.

name: Data-Centered Architecture
description: An architectural style that emphasizes the flow of data and events, often used in knowledge-based systems.

name: Repository Architecture
description: A data-centered architecture style that allows clients to interact with a data store, controlling logic flow and data access.

name: Student Class
description: A data bean representing a student record, encapsulating properties and methods for data manipulation.

name: Aggregation Relationship
description: A relationship where a collection class (Students) contains instances of another class (Student), indicating a whole-part relationship.

name: Serializable Interface
description: An interface implemented by the Student class to allow its instances to be serialized for storage or transmission.

name: Bidirectional Data Link
description: A characteristic of the architecture that allows for two-way data communication between components.

name: Control Flow Links
description: Links that manage the control over data and agents within the architecture, affecting the logic flow.

name: Blackboard Architecture
description: An architectural pattern that facilitates collaboration among independent knowledge sources to solve complex problems using a shared data store.

name: Knowledge Source
description: An entity that represents a specific area of expertise contributing to the problem-solving process within the blackboard architecture.

name: Data Store
description: The component that holds the current state of data in the blackboard architecture, directing the flow of computation.

name: Rule-Based Strategy
description: A design pattern that utilizes rules to trigger actions in knowledge sources based on changes in the blackboard.

name: Controller Subsystem
description: The component responsible for initiating the blackboard and knowledge sources, and periodically inspecting the state of the blackboard.

name: Activation Mechanism
description: A design pattern that allows knowledge sources to be triggered based on changes in the blackboard, facilitating dynamic problem-solving.

name: Blackboard Architecture
description: An architectural pattern suitable for solving complex problems by allowing multiple independent knowledge sources to collaborate.

name: Data-Centered Repository Architecture
description: An architecture where a data repository controls the logic flow, often used in layered and client-server architectures.

name: Scalability
description: The ability to easily add or update knowledge sources in a system, enhancing its capacity to handle growth.

name: Concurrency
description: The capability of multiple knowledge sources to operate in parallel, independent of each other, within the blackboard architecture.

name: Loose Coupling
description: A design principle that allows components to be independent, facilitating easier maintenance and scalability.

name: Agent
description: A component in the blackboard architecture that controls logic flow and interacts with the data store.

name: Knowledge Source
description: An independent entity in the blackboard architecture that provides specific expertise or data for problem-solving.

name: Virtual Machine
description: An architectural pattern that provides a virtual abstraction layer, allowing applications to run independently of the underlying hardware.

name: Java Virtual Machine (JVM)
description: A specific implementation of a virtual machine that enables Java programs to be platform-independent by interpreting bytecode.

name: Common Language Runtime (CLR)
description: The virtual machine component of the .NET framework that manages the execution of .NET programs and provides services such as garbage collection.

name: Interpreter
description: A design pattern that defines a representation for a grammar and provides an interpreter to evaluate sentences in the language.

name: Interpreter Execution Engine
description: An architectural pattern that simulates CPU operations for executing bytecode in a virtual machine.

name: Hierarchical Architecture
description: An architectural style that decomposes a system into layers, where each layer provides services to the upper layer.

name: Layered Architecture
description: A specific type of hierarchical architecture that organizes software into layers with defined responsibilities.

name: Portability
description: A software quality attribute that allows software to run on different platforms without modification.

name: Maintainability
description: A quality attribute that refers to the ease with which software can be modified to correct faults or improve performance.

name: Simulation
description: A domain-driven design concept that involves creating a model to replicate the behavior of a system.

name: Method Invocation
description: A programming construct used in hierarchical architecture for communication between layers.

name: Master-Slave Architecture
description: A variant of the main-subroutine architecture style that supports fault tolerance and system reliability.

name: Main-Subroutine Architecture
description: An architectural style that organizes software into a hierarchy of modules with a main control module and subordinate subroutines.

name: Transaction Flow
description: A flow that evaluates incoming data and decides on action paths, relevant in the context of domain-driven design.

name: Transform Flow
description: A flow that processes incoming data and transforms it, often isolated from other flows.

name: Transaction Center
description: A control module that manages transaction flows and action paths in a software architecture.

name: Action Module
description: Modules that represent specific actions in the transaction flow, responsible for processing tasks.

name: Control Module
description: A module that directs the flow of information processing in the architecture.

name: Fault Tolerance
description: A quality attribute that ensures a system continues to operate in the event of a failure.

name: System Reliability
description: A quality attribute that measures the ability of a system to perform its intended function consistently over time.

name: Hierarchical Architecture
description: An architectural style that organizes a software system into a hierarchy of modules, where lower-level modules provide services to upper-level modules.

name: Layered Architecture
description: An architectural pattern that separates concerns into layers, where each layer provides services to the layer above it.

name: Module
description: A logical unit of code that encapsulates related functions and procedures, often organized in a hierarchy.

name: Package
description: A namespace that organizes classes and interfaces in object-oriented programming, facilitating modularity and reusability.

name: Library
description: A collection of precompiled routines that a program can use, often organized to provide specific functionalities.

name: Service
description: A function or procedure provided by a module that can be invoked by other modules in the hierarchy.

name: I/O Services
description: Services that handle input and output operations, crucial for system functionality.

name: Business Logic
description: The part of the application that encodes the real-world business rules and processes.

name: Layered Architecture
description: An architectural pattern that separates concerns into layers, allowing for abstraction and decoupling of components.

name: Component
description: A modular unit of software that encapsulates a set of related functions and can be deployed independently.

name: User Interface Layer
description: The top layer in a layered architecture responsible for user interaction and presentation.

name: Processing Layer
description: The layer that handles business logic and processes requests from the user interface layer.

name: Maintainability
description: A software quality attribute that measures how easily a software system can be modified to correct faults, improve performance, or adapt to a changed environment.

name: Decoupling
description: A design principle that promotes reducing dependencies between components to enhance modularity.

description: An enhanced version of MVC-I where the View and Controller are separated, allowing for better modularity and division of labor.

description: Represents the data and core functionality of the application, notifying the View and Controller of changes.

description: A messaging architecture where messages are sent from a producer to a specific consumer via a message queue.

description: An architectural pattern that promotes the production, detection, consumption of, and reaction to events.

description: An architectural style that uses messages to communicate between components, allowing for loose coupling.

name: Loose Coupling
description: A design principle that aims to reduce dependencies between components, enhancing flexibility and maintainability.

name: Source
description: An event source class that triggers events and manages listener registration, allowing for concurrent event handling.

name: Event-Driven Architecture
description: An architectural pattern where the system is designed around the production, detection, consumption of, and reaction to events.

name: Message Topic

description: A design boundary within which a particular domain model is defined and applicable.

description: The principle of 'Don't Repeat Yourself' to reduce repetition of software patterns.

name: KISS Principle
description: The principle of 'Keep It Simple, Stupid' to avoid unnecessary complexity.

name: YAGNI Principle
description: The principle of 'You Aren't Gonna Need It' to avoid adding functionality until it is necessary.

name: Separation of Concerns
description: The practice of organizing code to separate different concerns or functionalities.

name: Client-Server Architecture
description: A distributed application structure that partitions tasks between service providers (servers) and service requesters (clients).

name: Microservices Architecture
description: An architectural style that structures an application as a collection of loosely coupled services, which implement business capabilities.

name: Layered Architecture
description: An architectural pattern that organizes the system into layers, each with specific responsibilities, promoting separation of concerns.

name: Event-Driven Architecture
description: An architectural pattern that uses events to trigger and communicate between decoupled services.

name: Publish-Subscribe Pattern
description: A messaging pattern where senders (publishers) do not send messages directly to specific receivers (subscribers), promoting loose coupling.

name: Module
description: A self-contained unit of code that encapsulates related functions and data, promoting code organization and reusability.

name: Package
description: A namespace that organizes a set of related classes and interfaces, facilitating modular programming.

name: Maintainability
description: The ease with which a software system can be modified to correct faults, improve performance, or adapt to a changed environment.

name: Scalability
description: The capability of a system to handle a growing amount of work or its potential to accommodate growth.

name: Performance
description: The efficiency of a software system in terms of response time and resource consumption.

name: Security
description: The protection of software systems against unauthorized access and alterations.

name: Reliability
description: The ability of a software system to consistently perform its intended functions under specified conditions.

name: Singleton Pattern
description: A creational design pattern that restricts the instantiation of a class to one single instance.

name: Factory Pattern
description: A creational design pattern that provides an interface for creating objects in a superclass but allows subclasses to alter the type of created objects.

name: Domain-Driven Design
description: An approach to software development that emphasizes collaboration between technical and domain experts to create a shared model.

name: Bounded Context
description: A boundary within which a particular model is defined and applicable, crucial for managing domain complexity.

name: Aggregate
description: A cluster of domain objects that can be treated as a single unit for data changes.

name: Entity
description: An object that is defined by its identity, rather than its attributes.

name: Value Object
description: An object that describes some characteristics or attributes but has no conceptual identity.

name: Ubiquitous Language
description: A common language used by both developers and domain experts to ensure clear communication.

description: A database normalization form that removes transitive dependencies, ensuring that non-key attributes are not dependent on other non-key attributes.

name: Fifth Normal Form (5 NF)
description: A database normalization form that ensures that every join dependency in the table is a consequence of the candidate keys.

name: bounded context
description: A boundary within which a particular domain model is defined and applicable.

name: aggregate
description: A cluster of domain objects that can be treated as a single unit for data changes.

description: An object that is defined by its identity, rather than its attributes.

description: An object that describes some characteristics or attributes but has no conceptual identity.

description: A common language used by both developers and non-developers to describe the domain.

description: A self-contained unit of code that encapsulates a set of related functionalities.

description: A container that holds a set of identifiers and allows disambiguation of homonym identifiers.

name: component
description: A modular part of a system that encapsulates a set of related functions and can be independently deployed.

name: creational design patterns
description: Design patterns that deal with object creation mechanisms.

name: structural design patterns
description: Design patterns that deal with object composition and typically help to define relationships between entities.

name: behavioral design patterns
description: Design patterns that focus on communication between objects.

name: singleton pattern
description: A design pattern that restricts a class to a single instance and provides a global point of access to it.

name: factory pattern
description: A creational design pattern that provides an interface for creating objects in a superclass but allows subclasses to alter the type of objects that will be created.

description: A physical or logical subnetwork that contains and exposes an organization's external services to an untrusted network.

description: A set of technologies that manage data traffic to reduce packet loss, latency, and jitter on a network.

name: Frequency Division Multiple Access (FDMA)
description: A channel access method used in multiple-access protocols that allows multiple users to access the same frequency band by dividing it into smaller frequency bands.

name: Time Division Multiple Access (TDMA)
description: A channel access method that allows multiple users to share the same frequency channel by dividing the signal into different time slots.

name: Space Division Multiple Access (SDMA)
description: A method of allowing multiple users to share the same frequency channel by using spatial separation.

name: Encapsulation
description: A mechanism used to implement abstraction by hiding the details of an object's representation and operations.

description: The process of simplifying complex systems by focusing on one level of detail at a time.

description: An organized structure of different levels of abstraction, which can be sequential or tree-structured.

name: Application Programming Interface (API)
description: A standard interface that allows different software components to communicate, enhancing portability and integration.

name: Finite State Machine (FSM)
description: A computational model used to design algorithms and systems that can be in one of a finite number of states at any given time.

name: State Transition Function
description: A function that defines how the FSM transitions from one state to another based on input symbols.

name: Output Function
description: A function that produces output based on the current state and input symbol in an FSM.

name: State Table
description: A tabular representation of the state transitions and outputs for an FSM, providing a clear overview of its behavior.

name: Grammar
description: A formal set of rules that defines the structure of a language, applicable in programming language design and compilers.

description: An abstraction process that involves creating a partial representation of a system to test hypotheses and gather feedback.

description: A functionally equivalent but incomplete representation that behaves like the physical artifact.

description: A higher level of abstraction using symbols to model processes or systems, aiding in understanding and prediction.

name: Discrete Simulation
description: A type of simulation focusing on event scheduling and modeling discrete events in software engineering.

description: The ability of a software system to consistently perform its intended functions under specified conditions.

name: Git Repository
description: A Git repository serves as a bounded context that encapsulates the state and history of a project.
source: The Architecture of Open Source Applications 2.pdf

name: Staging Area
description: The staging area in Git acts as an intermediary between the working directory and the repository, allowing for selective commits.
source: The Architecture of Open Source Applications 2.pdf

name: Object Database
description: The object database in Git stores all content or pointers to local content, ensuring immutability of objects once created.
source: The Architecture of Open Source Applications 2.pdf

name: Hooks
description: Hooks in Git are scripts that implement the Observer pattern, allowing for actions to be triggered on specific lifecycle events.
source: The Architecture of Open Source Applications 2.pdf

name: Runtime System (RTS)
description: The low-level code that manages execution of Haskell programs, crucial for performance and correctness.

name: Maintainability
description: The ease with which a system can be modified to correct faults, improve performance, or adapt to a changed environment.
source: The Architecture of Open Source Applications 2.pdf

name: Scalability
description: The capability of a system to handle a growing amount of work or its potential to accommodate growth.
source: The Architecture of Open Source Applications 2.pdf

name: Performance
description: The efficiency of the system in terms of response time and resource usage.

name: Security
description: The protection of information and property from theft, damage, or unauthorized access.

name: Reliability
description: The ability of a system to consistently perform its intended functions under specified conditions.

name: Bounded Context
description: A design boundary within which a particular domain model is defined and applicable.

name: Aggregate

name: Entity
description: An object that is defined by its identity, rather than its attributes.

name: Value Object

name: Facade
description: A structural design pattern that provides a simplified interface to a complex subsystem.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Module
description: A self-contained unit of code that encapsulates a specific functionality and can be reused across different parts of a system.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Smart Reference Proxy
description: A design pattern that provides a placeholder for another object to control access to it.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Virtual Proxy
description: A design pattern that acts as a surrogate for another object to control its instantiation and access.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Observer Pattern
description: A behavioral design pattern that defines a one-to-many dependency between objects so that when one object changes state, all its dependents are notified.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Singleton
description: A creational design pattern that restricts the instantiation of a class to a single instance and provides a global point of access to it.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Open-Closed Principle (OCP)
description: A design principle that states that software entities should be open for extension but closed for modification.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Dependency Inversion Principle
description: A design principle that suggests high-level modules should not depend on low-level modules but both should depend on abstractions.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Factory Pattern
description: A creational design pattern that provides an interface for creating objects in a superclass but allows subclasses to alter the type of objects that will be created.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Abstract Factory Pattern
description: A creational design pattern that provides an interface for creating families of related or dependent objects without specifying their concrete classes.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Adapter Pattern
description: A structural design pattern that allows objects with incompatible interfaces to work together.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Composite Pattern
description: A structural design pattern that lets you compose objects into tree structures to represent part-whole hierarchies.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Decorator Pattern
description: A structural design pattern that allows behavior to be added to individual objects, either statically or dynamically, without affecting the behavior of other objects from the same class.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Iterator Pattern
description: A behavioral design pattern that provides a way to access the elements of an aggregate object sequentially without exposing its underlying representation.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Decorator
description: Wraps an object to provide new behavior, allowing for dynamic behavior modification.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: State
description: Encapsulates state-based behaviors and uses delegation to switch between behaviors.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Iterator
description: Provides a way to traverse a collection of objects without exposing its implementation.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Facade
description: Simplifies the interface of a set of classes, providing a unified interface to a set of interfaces in a subsystem.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Strategy
description: Encapsulates interchangeable behaviors and uses delegation to decide which one to use.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Proxy
description: Wraps an object to control access to it, providing a surrogate or placeholder for another object.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Factory Method
description: Allows a client to create families of objects without specifying their concrete classes.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Adapter
description: Wraps an object and provides a different interface to it, allowing incompatible interfaces to work together.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Observer
description: Allows objects to be notified when state changes, promoting a publish-subscribe model.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Template Method
description: Subclasses decide how to implement steps in an algorithm, defining the skeleton of an algorithm in a method.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Composite
description: Clients treat collections of objects and individual objects uniformly, allowing for tree structures.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Singleton
description: Ensures one and only one object is created, providing a global point of access to it.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Abstract Factory
description: Provides an interface for creating families of related or dependent objects without specifying their concrete classes.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Command
description: Encapsulates a request as an object, allowing for parameterization of clients with queues, requests, and operations.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Bridge
description: Decouples an abstraction from its implementation, allowing both to vary independently.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: RemoteControl
description: An abstraction for controlling TV devices, allowing for varying implementations.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: SonyControl
description: Concrete implementation of RemoteControl for Sony TVs.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: RCAControl
description: Concrete implementation of RemoteControl for RCA TVs.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Bridge Pattern
description: A structural design pattern that decouples an abstraction from its implementation, allowing both to vary independently.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Builder Pattern
description: A creational design pattern that allows for the step-by-step construction of complex objects.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Chain of Responsibility Pattern
description: A behavioral design pattern that allows a request to be passed along a chain of handlers until one handles it.
source: [O`Reilly. Head First] - Head First Design Patterns 2nd Edition - [Freeman].pdf

name: Adapter Pattern
description: A structural design pattern that allows incompatible interfaces to work together by wrapping an existing class with a new interface.

name: Composite Pattern
description: A structural design pattern that allows you to compose objects into tree structures to represent part-whole hierarchies.

name: Decorator Pattern
description: A structural design pattern that allows behavior to be added to individual objects, either statically or dynamically, without affecting the behavior of other objects from the same class.

name: Cohesion
description: A design principle that refers to how closely related and focused the responsibilities of a single module are.

name: Virtual Proxy
description: A design pattern that provides a surrogate or placeholder for another object to control access to it.
